ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learning how to read systems papers and understanding a wide range of old and recent developments in distributed systems.
I was able to learn various kinds of architectures in distributed systems.

Efficiently connect the dots of distributed systems concepts and appreciate the core spirits performing systems design. Learned many state-of-the-art distributed systems example in industry / academia.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is organized in seminar style and incur discussions between students. It gave a lot of opportunities to talk freely in the class.

Strength: Everything is great Improvement: Maybe next time when a student holds a paper presentation, professor can reserve 15-20 min to talk about essential points because not every student presenter can reveal the important messages out of the papyer

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, with a series of important papers in distributed system design field to be read, students can form a clear insights into this area, and will be enabled to develop their own ideas of evaluating and even creating the prototype of a practical system.
This course provides advanced knowledge about building distributed systems.
